citations.narrative:
The facility did not have records of acquisition or animals on hand at the facility at time of inspection. The record of
animals on hand, with full acquisition and disposition records, are important to assure that all animals are located during
an emergency of natural disaster. Appropriate documentation of acquired regulated animals is essential for proper
identification, tracing forward and trace back of the animals. These records must be updated routinely and maintained in
the future to reflect animals on hand, animal arrivals and departures.
Correct by: November 15th ,2023.

The facility has not yet developed and documented a detailed contingency plan that addresses emergencies or disasters
that could reasonably be anticipated and expected to be detrimental to the health and well-being of the animals. A
contingency plan is required to provide for the humane handling, treatment, transportation, housing, and care of the
animals in the event of an emergency or disaster. The plan should identify the situations triggering the plan, outline the
tasks to be carried out, identify a chain of command, and address how the response and recovery will be handled. The
facility shall develop and document a detailed contingency plan.
Correct by November 15th, 2023.

The facility does not have a perimeter fence for the 24 kangaroos housed in outdoor enclosures. A perimeter fence is
necessary to act as a secondary containment system and to prevent unauthorized people or unwanted animals from
having access to the kangaroos. The absence of a perimeter fence can result in animal or human injury. The licensee
must ensure that all outdoor housing facilities are enclosed by a perimeter fence that is at least 6-feet-tall and at least 3-
feet from the primary enclosure and kept in good repair to protect the animals in the facility or obtain a variance in writing
from the Administrator.
Corrected by: May 1st, 2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
